title: High court weighs whether teen sniper deserves re-sentencing because he was a youth at the time
text:
Liberal and conservative justices seemed split on whether to grant a new sentencing hearing to Lee Boyd Malvo, who as a teenager was one of two snipers who terrorized the Washington area, killing 10 people.

The Supreme Court heard arguments Wednesday on whether Malvo was wrongly sentenced in Virginia to life without parole.

Malvo was 17 at the time of the killings. His attorneys say he deserves a new hearing because of recent Supreme Court rulings barring mandatory life sentences for juveniles.

A jury convicted Lee Boyd Malvo of capital murder in 2003 for sniper attacks in the Washington D.C. area. Malvo is seeking a re-sentence from the Supreme Court since he was 17 at the time of the deadly spree

This photo provided by the Virginia Department of Corrections shows Lee Boyd Malvo, who as a teenager was one of two snipers who terrorized the Washington area. Liberal and conservative justices seemed split on whether to grant him a new sentencing hearing

Virginia argues Malvo's life sentence was not mandatory because the judge theoretically had discretion to suspend part of Malvo's sentence after a jury recommended life without parole.

Malvo received two life sentences for the Fairfax County murder of FBI analyst Linda Franklin, who was shot in the parking lot of a Home Depot in Falls Church.

Under the new law at the time, Malvo was convicted of capital murder as an act of terrorism.

In 2002, Malvo and John Allen Muhammad paralyzed the neighborhoods surrounding the nation's capital with the seemingly random attacks.

File photo of Lee Boyd Malvo in 2002 at a pre-trial hearing. The 17-year-old and an accomplice killed 10 people during a three-week shooting rampage

John Allen Muhammad (center) would ultimately be executed for a murder during a 2002 shooting spree with 17-year-old Lee Boyd Malvo

Muhammad was executed in 2009, for the Prince William County, Virginia, murder of Dean Harold Meyers.

However, In June 2017, a federal appeals court threw out Malvo’s four Virginia sentences, and ordered he be resentenced in light of the Supreme Court rulings regarding life sentences for juveniles. Malvo is now 34.

Malvo is also serving six life-without-parole terms in Maryland.

Elena Kagan, a justice on the court's liberal wing, said the high court's previous rulings on the subject should be understood broadly, and that courts are bound to give serious consideration to the notion that "youth matters" in determining a juvenile's sentence.

On the other side, conservative Justice Samuel Alito suggested the court should simply apply the wording from its earlier case, which bans only mandatory life sentences without parole for juveniles. Because Virginia's Supreme Court has already ruled that Malvo's trial judge had discretion to lower Malvo's sentence, he would not be entitled to any relief under the court's previous ruling.

This is latest case to reach to the Supreme Court seeking specific guidelines for children convicted in brutal crimes. Beginning in 2005, the court ruled that minors can not be sentenced to death. In the years that followed, the court also removed life without parole sentences for all offenses excluding murder.
description: The Supreme Court heard arguments that Malvo was wrongly sentenced to life without parole in Virginia. Lee Boyd Malvo was 17 when he joined another sniper to kill 10 people in and around D.C.
